Hammond, Geoffrey P/C-7005-2008	Hammond, Geoffrey P/0000-0002-0922-8728; Norman, Jonathan/0000-0002-4139-6828	UK Research Council: the Economic and Social Research Council; UK Research Council: the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC); UK Research Council: Natural Environment Research Council; Great Western Research Alliance; EPSRC, UK Indemand Centre [EP/K011774/1]; EDF Energy and EDF RD (Ecleer); UKERC; Engineering and Physical Sciences Research CouncilEngineering & Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) [EP/L024756/1, EP/K011774/1] Funding Source: Researchfish	The funded research of the second author (GPH) on industrial energy demand and carbon dioxide emissions reduction forms part of the core research programme of the UK Energy Research Centre (UKERC); Phase II renewed in 2009. This national centre is funded by three of the UK Research Councils: the Economic and Social Research Council, the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) and the Natural Environment Research Council. The first author (PWG) and third author (JBN) undertook the work for this paper while funded by a UKERC flexible funding project entitled 'Industrial Energy Use from a Bottom-Up Perspective' (for which GPH was the principal investigator). The 2013 UKERC Industrial Energy Use from a Bottom-Up Perspective: Usable Energy Database (Beta Version) was the main output of the latter study. In addition, part of the work was undertaken during PWG's and JBN's doctoral research studies, which were supported by research studentships funded by UKERC, and the Great Western Research Alliance, EDF Energy and EDF R&D (Ecleer), respectively. GPH and JBN continue to work on the field of industrial energy demand reduction and material efficiency supported by funding from the EPSRC as part of the UK Indemand Centre (grant EP/K011774/1) as a co-investigator and research fellow, respectively. All authors are grateful to the 'Getting the Numbers Right' project management committee of the Cement Sustainability Initiative; Diana Casey (previously Edwards) of the Mineral Products Association, and Dylan Moore, creator of www.cementkilns.co.uk for their help in providing and interpreting information on the UK cement sector.
